The River Roding suffered 22 sewer spills in one day:
Our data request for the 8th May shows there were 22 overflows from 14 different sites. After 11mm of rain.
They discharged for almost 100 hours (volume is not recorded).
All have monitors, no one was told. This must change. https://t.co/fRNo8mGPwQ

tweets.text:
@amy_flanagandy @NestleUKI @EnvAgencyMids @derbyshiredales @PeakDistrictUK Looks like a normal tracer test. Standard procedure in hydro geology. Feel free to educate yourself before you complain:

https://t.co/yUrWw1rbzL

This is a very good point (& made at 2:36am, I note).

I analysed the dataset from Galingale View and averaged readings over 12 hours.

The following nights in April averaged over 100ug/m3 (date given is the morning as peak usually then):

4th
13th (over 150)
14th
17th
20th https://t.co/QgUHEAPmBp

tweets.text: @amy_flanagandy @EnvAgencyMids @derbyshiredales @PeakDistrictUK The test uses a dye that is completely safe to human and aquatic life and used internationally by hydrogeologists. On this occasion, the dye flowed unusually quick through the water, turning the river green. The colour will disperse quickly as the dye dilutes downstream. (2/2)
